titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the John Marshall Papers FA053
titlestmt.author: Emily J. Oakhill

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-02-17 09:10:58 -0500.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: John Marshall (1903-1980) was born in Portland, Maine, completed undergraduate (1925) and graduate (1928) studies, and taught in the English department (1927-1933) at Harvard University. In 1933 he joined the Rockefeller Foundation as Assistant (later Associate) Director of the newly formed Humanities program, and from 1933 to 1940 served as a Director of Education with the General Education Board.

As an officer with the Rockefeller Foundation in a newly formed program, Mr. Marshall explored not only specific projects, but the concept of the humanities as a field. Mr. Marshall developed a concern in promoting world-wide culture, with a special interest in the Near East. The Rockefeller Foundation funding for the arts and humanities from 1933 to 1950 was approximately $4 million. Between 1951 and 1960, the support increased to $8.4 million, supporting projects in areas including language, radio, and motion pictures.

Mr. Marshall remained an Associate Director for the Humanities program when appointed as the first director for the newly acquired Villa Serbelloni in Bellagio, Italy, in 1959. The Villa was (and continues to be) used as a retreat for scholars in a variety of disciplines who were were working on intensive projects and as a conference center for international meetings focused on significant issues or scientific developments. As director, Marshall worked to develop the direction for the Villa, while maintaining his connections with the European humanities community.

John Marshall was married to Mary Gardner Marshall (1927-1960) and Charlotte Trowbridge Koechl Marshall (1961), and had two children from his first marriage, Mary Elizabeth Scott and Ann (Sister Mary John OSB). He was the author of "Classic Cooking" (1959).
Mr. Marshall retired from the Foundation in 1970 and died in 1980.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The John Marshall Papers include correspondence, reports, speeches, articles, trip diaries, and photograph negatives. Materials span a period from his last semester at Harvard to condolences his widow received after his death. The bulk of the collection dates from 1940 to 1962.

The strength of the papers is that they reflect a more personal side to the humanities grant making of the Rockefeller Foundation. Mr. Marshall's personal correspondence differs greatly from that which was filed in the Rockefeller Foundation project files.

There is a great deal of material which documents the Rockefeller Foundation as a whole during the period, both in files pertaining to individuals, and in the files specifically identified as Rockefeller Foundation. There is extensive correspondence with individual grantees which does not appear in the official record of the Foundation, (Sisam, Flexner, St. John Perse) and correspondence commenting on specific grants by individuals who were not connected to them (Kirstein, Makinsky).

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The John Marshall Papers are divided into three series:

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: John Marshall was interviewed by the Columbia University Oral History Program in 1971. The transcript of the oral history interview, open with Mrs. Marshall's permission, is found in Record Group 13 of the Rockefeller Foundation Archives. Mr. Marshall's work at the Villa Serbelloni is documented in Record Group 3.2. His work as a director of the Humanities program of the Rockefeller Foundation is found in Record Group 3.1, and his diaries in Record Group 12 (almost seven cubic feet)document his work from 1933 to 1960.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The papers of John Marshall come from two sources. The general files were given to the Rockefeller University by Charlotte Marshall (Mrs. John Marshall) in 1985. The Villa Serbelloni files were transferred from the Rockefeller Foundation.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged alphabetically by correspondent or topic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes material relating directly to Rockefeller Foundation activities and to John Marshall's professional work.

The files of speeches, articles, and thought pieces in Series 1 cover a range of topics and reflect Mr. Marshall's thoughts on the humanities program, 1933-1970. Most, but not all, were authorized by Mr. Marshall.

Of special interest are the David H. Stevens file, which includes notes on his tenure at the Rockefeller Foundation and on Rockefeller Foundation Humanities personnel, 1929-1950, and the folder of General Education Board material, which deals with a review of interpretation at Colonial Williamsburg in 1939.

scopecontent.p: Accounting of London listing various aspects of life, their condition and costs.

scopecontent.p: England, Beirut, Egypt, Baghdad, Syria, Istanbul, Ankara.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes summary reports on Egypt and Iraq.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Los Angeles, San Francisco, Portland, Seattle, Vancouver, Chicago, Louisville. Includes itinerary and program for 'Macbeth' in San Francisco on October 1. Diary only written through October 3.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Egypt, Lebanon, Baghdad, Istanbul, Ankara. Includes conversations and visits to past Rockefeller Foundation grantees as well as present and future ones. Talks with important artists, scholars and officials in the areas visited.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Philanthropy in Turkey.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: England, Netherlands, Switzerland, Paris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes itinerary and local newspaper clippings.

scopecontent.p: Includes proposal for book that became "An American Saga," which Flexner worked on while a resident at the Villa Serbelloni.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note

did.unittitle: Speeches, Articles, and Thought Pieces - Miscellaneous

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Radio and motion pictures [their role in child development] notes for speech,undated; "Maalesh" excerpt by Jean Cocteau (in French), undated; Theater, undated (2); Travel, visit to post-war Europe outline, undated; University faculty, undated; "Public Opinion and The Emergency" memoranda from a [Rockefeller Foundation] group discussing the role of mass media after war was declared in Europe, November 1, 1939; Quotation from Paris Sous l'Occupation, by Jean-Paul Sartre, "La France Libre," November 15, 1944, Vol IX, no. 49; USSR/US/British diplomacy, September 23, 1946; "Spelman Messenger," August 1949, John Marshall gave the commencement address, June 6, 1949; also draft of speech topics include United Nations Education Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO), literature, importance of humanities; "The Vegetal Radicalism of Theodore Roethke", review in "The Sewanee Review", Winter 1950; "Radio's Uncertain Future" unpublished article, December 1950; Near East as viewed by American Education, 1951; Pugwash Conference on the Middle East, August 24, 1956.

did.unittitle: Speeches, Articles, and Thought Pieces - Rockefeller Foundation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Undated pieces: Criticism of the Humanities; Global war and the Rockefeller Foundation; Humanistic growth in the United States (2); Humanities audience; Humanities in Europe; Humanities and Foundations; Mass Communication; North American Regional Studies in the Rockefeller Foundation Humanities Program; Rockefeller Foundation in Post-war Great Britain; Widening Humanities; Working grammar for Foundation Officers in the arts.

did.unittitle: Speeches, Articles, and Thought Pieces - Rockefeller Foundation (A - Humanities)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Adventuring in the Arts," The Rockefeller Foundation Confidential Monthly Report to the Trustees, written by Charles B. Fahs, and a special section on Music written by Marshall, April 1958; "Adventuring in the Arts" source material for the above and for a planned version on literature; Definition of a Foundation Officer, February 16, 1958; Exploring the American heritage, 1942, Article from the St. Paul "Dispatch"; Far Eastern Studies, February 19, 1946; History of the Rockefeller Foundation's program in the Humanities [1959]; Humanities [1953]; "Humanities Program and Related Foundation Interests in History 1950-1960."

did.unittitle: Speeches, Articles, and Thought Pieces - Rockefeller Foundation (Humanists - North American)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Humanists "Another Voice" February 19, 1945; International Library service "Books Across Frontiers" [1950]; Language program 1942; Library of Congress [1943]; Literature and Philanthropy October 1958; Near East trip 1950 talk to Rockefeller Foundation staff; North American studies May 5, 1942.

did.unittitle: Speeches, Articles, and Thought Pieces - Rockefeller Foundation - Program

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Program in the Humanities," The Rockefeller Foundation Confidential Monthly Report to the Trustees, February 1, 1951; "Relations of the Foundation with Governmental and Intergovernmental Agencies," 1950; Rockefeller Foundation in Post-war Europe, January 29, 1947; Rockefeller Foundation in underdeveloped countries (at the expense of established European and North American programs) 3 versions; "Supply of Minds," 1946; "The Symbol of History," Excerpt from Raymond B. Fosdick's Presidential Review 1944, includes total annual appropriations 1933-1944; "What to Do About the Humanities?" 1943 [?] article by George A. Lundberg about the position of the humanities in education with John Marshall's response (unpublished) and correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes biographical sketches of Rockefeller Foundation Humanities personnel.

did.unittitle: United Nations Education Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes Warren Weaver articles, correspondence, Lewis Carroll/"Alice in Wonderland".

did.unittitle: Christmas Greetings to John Marshall from the Philharmonia Hungarica (oversize material)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The series documents the beginnings of the Villa Serbelloni program from John Marshall's first days at the Villa. The bulk of the series dates prior to 1963, at which time correspondence and filing procedures were established and all documents concerning the Villa went directly through the Rockefeller Foundation's records management program. These documents are found in Record Group 3.2 of the Rockefeller Foundation Archives.

Especially interesting are the diaries for 1960 when it was not clear what the Villa program was going to be and Mr. Marshall traveled through Europe looking for possibilities. Included in this series is a copy of John Marshall's unpublished history of the Villa.
Mr. Marshall's file titles have been largely unchanged in this series.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Rockefeller Foundation Archives, Record Group 3.2, Series 900, files on Villa Serbelloni.

did.unittitle: Anderle, Othman - Institute for Theoretische Geschichte

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: John Marshall (1903-1980) was born in Portland, Maine, completed undergraduate (1925) and graduate (1928) studies, and taught in the English department (1927-1933) at Harvard University. In 1933 he joined the Rockefeller Foundation as Assistant (later Associate) Director of the newly formed Humanities program, and from 1933 to 1940 served as a Director of Education with the General Education Board.

As an officer with the Rockefeller Foundation in a newly formed program, Mr. Marshall explored not only specific projects, but the concept of the humanities as a field. Mr. Marshall developed a concern in promoting world-wide culture, with a special interest in the Near East. The Rockefeller Foundation funding for the arts and humanities from 1933 to 1950 was approximately $4 million. Between 1951 and 1960, the support increased to $8.4 million, supporting projects in areas including language, radio, and motion pictures.

Mr. Marshall remained an Associate Director for the Humanities program when appointed as the first director for the newly acquired Villa Serbelloni in Bellagio, Italy, in 1959. The Villa was (and continues to be) used as a retreat for scholars in a variety of disciplines who were were working on intensive projects and as a conference center for international meetings focused on significant issues or scientific developments. As director, Marshall worked to develop the direction for the Villa, while maintaining his connections with the European humanities community.

John Marshall was married to Mary Gardner Marshall (1927-1960) and Charlotte Trowbridge Koechl Marshall (1961), and had two children from his first marriage, Mary Elizabeth Scott and Ann (Sister Mary John OSB). He was the author of "Classic Cooking" (1959).
Mr. Marshall retired from the Foundation in 1970 and died in 1980.
